awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dynamics, Correlations and Disorder in Topological Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports integrated theoretical research and education focused on the role of external driving forces, strong interactions among electrons, and defects and imperfections in topological states of electronic matter. Topological states are characterized by properties that in a fundamental sense have a geometric origin and are unchanged by small changes of the material, and are connected to states around the surface and edges of the material that can conduct electricity without dissipation, even when the bulk is insulating. The research thrusts are aimed at formulating concepts to advance understanding of topological states. They address specific questions of practical importance by virtue of studying realistic physical systems and their potential applications. This project may contribute to the foundations of new technologies such as quantum computation, precision metrology, energy conversion, and low-power electronic devices. The integrated education activities will bring recent scientific advances and new concepts to high school students of diverse socio-economic and ethnic backgrounds. Educational materials developed will be made publicly available. This effort will be informed by, and will contribute to, science education research and the nation's strategic education needs to meet the challenge of finding and utilizing the materials of future technologies. The Principle Investigator will also help improve the participation and diversity of students in science through existing efforts at Indiana University.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports the Principle Investigator's (PI) integrated research, education and outreach activities focused on the role of non-equilibrium dynamics, correlations and disorder in topological states of matter, especially in topological insulators and superconductors, and their potential applications. These activities have three aims:
1. To study the dynamical properties of topological states, in particular the realization, detection and manipulation of topological bound states, such as Majorana fermions, in periodically driven systems.
2. To study disorder and fluctuations in dynamic and static topological states, especially their role in the realization of novel correlated topological states of matter, and the topological protection of quantum information and their applications.
3. To institute an integrated and broad educational and outreach effort at K-12, undergraduate and graduate levels that fosters the students' understanding of organizational principles in condensed matter - including the role of topology, promotes the diversity of students in science, and prepares the next generation of scientists.

The PI will use analytical approaches and numerical simulations combining models of various levels sophistication to elucidate the conceptual framework as well as the physically relevant properties and phenomena of real systems. The educational and outreach activities include the project Forefronts of Research Education Modules to develop short, inquiry-based units that bring recent advances to high school physics classrooms as well as summer research experience for underrepresented students and a seminar series for undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a broad and foundational research and educational program at the forefronts of our understanding of the quantum dynamics of topological phases of matter.

The major research findings supported by this award include:

  • A proposal for optically controlled valley switch in graphene and other two-dimensional Dirac material;
  • A proposal for dynamical interferometry of Majorana bound states, allowing to detect and manipulate them in nanoscale solid state and synthetic quantum systems to enable their use in topological quantum devices;
  • An optimal protocol for Majorana-based quantum gates;
  • A unified Floquet linear response theory with applications in calculating the optical response of periodically driven quantum systems;
  • A unified Floquet perturbation theory for periodically driven quantum systems, offering a systematic analytical framework in the notoriously difficult-to-access low-frequency regime;
  • The first comprehensive study of the low-frequency limit in a periodically driven quantum systems, revealing a highly structured approach to adiabatic evolution and universal fluctuations of Floquet topological invariants;
  • Uncovering the unique signature of Floquet topological phases in their quantum noise spectrum;
  • A proposal for direct measurement of Floquet topological invariants in periodically driven ultracold atoms in optical lattices;
  • The first proposal to engineer higher-order Floquet topological phases with dynamically generated corner and hinge bound states;
  • The first proposal to engineer isolated topological flatbands in twisted bilayer graphene irradiated by circularly polarize laser;
  • The introduction of the concept of dynamically induced topology in a trivial metallic medium following contact with the edge of a static topological insulator or superconductor;
  • The introduction of the concept of a Floquet gauge pump, whereby a dynamically engineered Floquet Hamiltonian is employed to reveal the inherent degeneracy of the ground state in interacting systems.

These findings form a coherent body that advances our fundamental understanding of topological phases of quantum matter in and out of equilibrium and provides state-of-the-art tools for their realization, manipulation, and detection. A few highlights follow:

Fundamental understanding of driven quantum systems

1) In a Physical Review Letters publication, we reported the first comprehensive study of the low-frequency dynamics of periodically driven (Floquet) topological phases. We discovered universal fluctuations of the Floquet topological invariants that characterize the dynamics of the system as the frequency is lowered. We uncovered a diffusive structure causing these fluctuations and, thus, demonstrated that the adiabatic limit of a Floquet topological insulator is highly structured.

2) In an open-access publication in New Journal Physics, we developed a unified perturbation theory for periodically driven quantum systems, which puts the high- and low-frequency approximations to the Floquet theory on the same footing. In particular, our formalism captures adiabatic perturbation theories as well as diabatic deviation due to Floquet resonances. We illustrated the utility of the theory in reproducing the dynamics of two-level systems. This framework offers a promising outlook for understanding the low-frequency dynamics of interacting driven systems.

Realization and detection of novel dynamical phases of matter

1) Unlike electric charge, valley degrees of freedom provide a low-dissipation resource for quantum information processing. In research published in Physical Review Letters, we showed that an intense laser can produce highly polarized and optically controlled valley currents in graphene. We demonstrated the robustness of the valley current against moderate disorder and small deviations in optical parameters.

2) In a publication highlighted as Editors' Suggestion in Physical Review B, we demonstrated the existence of dynamically generated phases with localized states protected by the higher-order topology induced by the periodic drive. We characterized a new class of higher-order ?anomalous? Floquet topological phase, where the corners of the open system host Floquet bound states with the same as well as with double the period of the drive. Moreover, we proposed ?stirring drive protocol? to realize bulk vortex structures dynamically and host multiple Floquet bound states. This work establishes Floquet engineering of higher-order topological phases and bulk defects and offers a versatile tool for dynamical generation and control of topologically protected Floquet corner and bulk bound states.

3) We proposed a feasible scheme for measuring the topological numbers characterizing the dynamics of a periodically driven optical lattice efficiently and directly. This proposal, published in Physical Review Letters, constructs a family of drives that connect the driven system of interest to a topologically trivial reference system through a process similar to crystallography in the temporal direction. The topological numbers are then measured by an efficient tomographic scheme near singular points as one sweeps across the family of drives.

The education effort supported by this award brought together educators, students, and researchers to create the Forefronts Of Research Educational Modules (FOREM). These modules were tested in local high schools and are available freely to all educators. Through workshops and classroom deployment, Project FOREM provides examples of hands-on, active-learning educational modules that bring concepts and viewpoints at the forefronts of physics research to inspire and engage the future generation of scientists.
